review: British readers are going to go crazy for this, Antoine Laurain's latest slice of Parisian whimsy.His books are always sweet and fun to read but VintaBritish readers are going to go crazy for this, Antoine Laurain's latest slice of Parisian whimsy.His books are always sweet and fun to read but Vintage 1954 kicks the nostalgia into overdrive. Four people are transported back to 1954 Paris from the present day after sharing a bottle of vintage wine. Here they encounter the great figures of the age - Dali, Truffaut, Godard, Hepburn, Prevert et al - and learn a little about how life has changed in the intervening 65 years.Non-Parisians will, I'm sure, be enchanted by the idea of Old Paris and there is much to be said for such a happy positive book. My only criticism is that it is all perhaps a little too sweet and easy....more

review: Absolutely cracking read. A proper slice of southern gothic with an extraordinary narrative voice.Pearl lives in a car on a two-bit Florida trailer paAbsolutely cracking read. A proper slice of southern gothic with an extraordinary narrative voice.Pearl lives in a car on a two-bit Florida trailer park with her mother. She walks to school, her mother works at the nearby vets' hospital, their world stinks of the local garbage dump. That's the way it's always been.But things are stirring in the background. Everyone on the trailer park is up to something, not least Pastor Rex, whose guns-for-god scheme may not be the force for good he claims. When Eli, a strange no-good man turns up one day, it upsets the whole equilibrium of Pearl's simple life in the most violent of ways.Written in a simply stunning poetic style and featuring a wonderfully believable narrator - the unforgettable Pearl - this is one of the best novels I've read all year. review: I love Stewart Lee and this book provides an interesting insight into what goes into producing stand-up comedy. You see a guy performing comedy - espeI love Stewart Lee and this book provides an interesting insight into what goes into producing stand-up comedy. You see a guy performing comedy - especially someone like Lee who uses so much apparent improvisation - and think, 'he's a naturally funny person'. But this book shows just how much painstaking work goes into every joke, every pretend improvisation, every aspect of the show. Told in the form of transcripts of Lee's comeback shows in the early 2000s, it includes annotations about the source of each joke as well as essays on his mental state at the time....more

They are expecting Maurice's daughter, missing three years and suspected of living in a sort-of commune on one side or the other of the Mediterranean.As they wait, they interrogate various 'crusties' - anyone with dreadlocks and a dog - about her whereabouts. There is a cloud of threat and some minor violence, all presented with Barry's signature style and bags of humour.But, as we delve into the back story of Maurice and Charlie's intimately linked history, the novel evolves into something tender, emotional and wholly refreshing. review: This is a disturbing, unrealistic and quite nasty book about sexual obsession. Adele escapes the banality of domesticity by seeking out damaging, grotThis is a disturbing, unrealistic and quite nasty book about sexual obsession. Adele escapes the banality of domesticity by seeking out damaging, grotesque and often abusive sexual relationships. Everyone suffers from her actions; her young son, her friends, her husband and, ultimately, Adele herself. Her career as a journalist crumbles, her marriage is in ruins, her mental health spirals.I'm not sure what the thrust of the book really is. Exploration of sexual addiction? A comment on bourgeois society? A titillating sexual thriller? But it doesn't fully work on any level. There's just not enough depth to the story or the characters and it all leaves a sour taste.This is the second book on the subject I've read recently and, though very different, Tom Perrotta's Mrs Fletcher handles sexual addiction much better with far more relatable characters....more

title: The Long Take
author: Robertson, Robin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A wonderful experiment and a beautiful, harrowing account of PTSD.A Canadian soldier suffering terribly from the effects of WW2 tries to build a life A wonderful experiment and a beautiful, harrowing account of PTSD.A Canadian soldier suffering terribly from the effects of WW2 tries to build a life for himself in LA. He finds work as a reporter but is haunted constantly by memories of what he has seen and done. And the reminders are everywhere - explosions as buildings are torn down and rebuilt; new year's celebration fireworks; scores of homeless, drunk vets on the streets.This is a bleak and brutal tale which, written mostly as a longform poem, could have been gimmicky. But it works wonderfully. Telling a novel-length story in this way opens new doors where others close. Sure, characterisation is harder in this format, but a new world of imagery is suddenly possible. Some sections describing the city are as beautiful as any I've read. And the flashbacks to WW2 battlefields are shocking, raw and hugely affecting.Killer ending, too....more

title: Mrs. Fletcher
author: Perrotta, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a delight. This is a sweet, funny novel that tackles some serious and very contemporary issues, namely 21st century sexual politics.Eve Fletcher What a delight. This is a sweet, funny novel that tackles some serious and very contemporary issues, namely 21st century sexual politics.Eve Fletcher has sent her son off to college and it's left a huge void in her life; she fills it with an addiction to internet pornography. Suddenly is seems like every person and situation has the potential to become sexualised. Eve stumbles along, trying to convince herself she is exploring her sexuality and finally making a mark on the world, freed from the shackles of domesticity. But things start to unravel and she finds her decisions affecting her work and her mental state.Meanwhile, her son Brendan is busy negotiating the pitfalls of sexual consent, or not, and facing the fallout from the #MeToo movement.This could so easily have become a farce, or turned overly sexual, but Perrotta pitches it perfectly. It's funny, awkward and peopled in the main with realistic characters. There is even a fairly fully-developed trans character.Perrotta's novel is ambitious in that it tackles such a wide range of very modern issues but he pulls it off pretty well. It is a little spoiled by a rather silly ending but is still a funny, urgent novel and we'll worth a read....more

title: The Parade
author: Eggers, Dave
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An enjoyable, strange satire, which is about as fresh and far removed from most American literature as you are likely to find.The Parade follows the cAn enjoyable, strange satire, which is about as fresh and far removed from most American literature as you are likely to find.The Parade follows the construction of a long straight road connecting the north and south of a middle eastern country recently ravaged by civil war. The two workers building this road are western, employees of a large, wealthy company, and are known to each other only by numbers they have assigned themselves.Four and Nine, as they are called, are polar opposites; one a focused, driven company man; the other a libertine, more interested in the local hospitality than the job at hand. The tension between the two thinly-sketched characters works nicely as they wind their way through this ruined country.A huge parade has been promised at their endpoint, the Capital, and the pair must negotiate curious locals, smatterings of rebels and eachother if they are to make it in time.The whole book has a wonderful fable-like quality to it, though the ending is rushed and not entirely satisfactory.Still, it is an enjoyable, fast read and is certainly recommended....more

review: There's been a fair bit of negativity around this latest of the many posthumously-published novels of the great Bolano. But I think it's a little unfaThere's been a fair bit of negativity around this latest of the many posthumously-published novels of the great Bolano. But I think it's a little unfair.I mean, it aint The Savage Detectives, but even when he isn't at his best you feel you are in the hands of an undisputed genius. Like a diluted version of TSD, this follows two young, bohemian poets as they traipse around Mexico City trying to confirm the rumour that there are over 600 literary magazines in publication within the city limits.This is a disjointed, self-indulgent book. But there are enough glimmers of brilliance that it makes it well worth the read for established fans. The prose, as always, is exquisite. And the last section is a brilliantly sustained, highly effective piece of disturbing writing....more

title: Doggerland

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a wonderful novel. An old man and a boy live their lives on a rig in the north sea, repairing turbines on a giant wind farm. An ecological event What a wonderful novel. An old man and a boy live their lives on a rig in the north sea, repairing turbines on a giant wind farm. An ecological event has seen the world ripped of its resources, only plastic and electricity seem in rich health.Their days are mundane: travelling around the farm in their rechargeable boat, carrying out repairs for 'The Company', keeping the blades turning, eating bland manufactured food, playing pool, dredging the seabed for useless items. All there is, apart from the water, is their clipped conversation and the quarterly visit from a supply boat.The boy is there because his father deserted his post and he has been sent to fulfill the contract. The old man has resigned himself to this repetitive, pointless life. Until the boy plans their escape...Smith's prose is utterly exquisite, spare as Cynan Jones, with dialogue straight out of Beckett. And the story is told with such restraint and beauty that is drags at your heart and your gut when things go south. It's a magnificent novel and should go on to win many awards this year....more

review: This is gritty, raw Mexican noir with a violent, bloody plot and hideous, corrupt, immoral characters. And it is very well done.The teenage daughter oThis is gritty, raw Mexican noir with a violent, bloody plot and hideous, corrupt, immoral characters. And it is very well done.The teenage daughter of a rich businessman is kidnapped and ex-detective Carlos Trevino is hired to find her. He scours the backstreets of the fictional coastal resort of La Eternidad, a town caught in the middle of a bloody territorial war between two drug cartels.Alongside Trevino's search is the story of Police Chief Margarito, a man whose decades of corrupt, murderous rule are about to come to an end, by either retirement or the payback of those he has wronged - whichever comes first.As in James Ellroy's best work, Solares has created a world filled to the brim with awful people in a town where everyone is on the take and bodies are dropped at an alarming rate. He doesn't quite have the panache of Ellroy, nor the cinematic quality of Don Winslow, but his storytelling is hardboiled and moves at a thrilling pace. A cracking slice of seedy Mexican noir....more

title: You Can't Catch Death
author: Brautigan, Ianthe
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a certain romance around the tortured genius, the alcoholic writer. If he kills himself with a shot from a .44 Magnum? Great, bring it on, it There's a certain romance around the tortured genius, the alcoholic writer. If he kills himself with a shot from a .44 Magnum? Great, bring it on, it only adds to the legacy.Ianthe Brautigan's memoir of her father Richard tears away the romance of his death, of his periods of alcohol abuse, and tells not just of the wonderful man he was but also the effect his devastating final act had on her life.Brautigan, according to his daughter, was everything you'd hope he would be from reading his glorious books: eccentric, loving, poetic, romantic and turbulent.But he had a dark side, too. Weeks of benders resulted in him smashing furniture and shooting holes in the walls of his ranch while his teenage daughter failed to sleep upstairs. He first spoke to Ianthe about killing himself when she was just nine. His sudden and incredible fame was unwelcome, but his fall from favour and bad s towards the end of his life cut deep, culminating in his suicide in 1984.This is a deeply poetic book, full of raw emotion and drenched in love and regret for her genius father. It sometimes reads like what it is - a book written less to be read than as an act of catharsis. But that only adds to the authenticity of this sad and very real meditation on grief, death and family....more

title: The Order of the Day
author: Vuillard, Éric
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This stunning, mesmerising short novel (really it's more like 'opinionated non-fiction') attacks the received wisdom that history is inevitable and thThis stunning, mesmerising short novel (really it's more like 'opinionated non-fiction') attacks the received wisdom that history is inevitable and that our collective certainties are truth.Through a series of embellished set pieces Vuillard, a French film-maker and novelist, brings us the catastrophic lead-up to WW2.There are legendary funding drives at meetings between Hitler and the titans of German industry, the intimidation of the Austrian hierarchy, lunches between Chamberlain and a Nazi foreign minister. Vuillard approaches each with an unasked question - could you really not see what was coming? He also questions our view of proceedings. History, at least when it is taught in schools, likes to put things in simple boxes. If the Nazis are evil, as we all agree, then those who opposed them must be good, must have been 'saving' us? Vuillard challenges that notion. He attempts to expose the charade of the Anschluss, of appeasement, of millionaires' support for the Nazis, for what they were - political posturing.Much of what is written here will be familiar to seasoned historians but for the layman like myself it is all fascinating and quite chilling.This is a gripping and highly readable book which should be foisted upon politicians the world over to remind them that time will one day make them accountable for their actions....more

title: The Wolf and the Watchman: 1793
author: Natt och Dag, Niklas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This isn't normally the kind of book I'd reach for but I quite enjoyed it. I mean, it's overwritten and a bit clunky at times. But it comes together iThis isn't normally the kind of book I'd reach for but I quite enjoyed it. I mean, it's overwritten and a bit clunky at times. But it comes together in the end.Set in Stockholm in the late 18th century, it depicts a city full of sickness, severed limbs and the scents of rotting shit. A truly disgusting place.Amid all this, a limbless, eyeless, toothless torso is fished out if the festering water. It is then left to an odd couple team of investigators to find the identity of the body and how it met its grisly end.The story unfolds against the backdrop of great political and royal upheaval, with the Swedish King Gustav recently assassinated and Mary Antoinette about to lose her head.It reads almost like a very bleak and disgusting Sherlock Holmes at times (one scene in particular is one if the most harrowing things I have read). And certain parts reminded me of Varenne's Retribution Road, though it's not as gritty or as well written. As I mentioned above, it is a bit overwritten and a lot of the middle part could have easily been dropped.But it is an enjoyable read and does a good job of conjuring up the fetid stink and horrific sights of a rotting city and its bereft citizens....more

review: "What does it taste of?""A bit like veal."Now, I love dark, grim, grisly books. But this really is a bit too far. In 1870, a young nobleman goes to th"What does it taste of?""A bit like veal."Now, I love dark, grim, grisly books. But this really is a bit too far. In 1870, a young nobleman goes to the village fair, where he finds the locals are drunk, sweltering in the sun and ramped up on war rhetoric.After a misheard comment, he spends two hours being abused, tortured, cooked and eventually eaten by the crazed mob.There would be a great deal of absurdist, macabre humour in the elongated torture scenes and the following cannibalistic bread-and-dripping feast, if it weren't for one thing... The whole affair is based on a true story. The utterly horrific events took place in a small village in France, during the Franco-Prussian war.In all honesty, the writing isn't particularly good and, were it not for the notorious nature of the subject matter, it would never have been published....more

review: Jesus, that was a dark and disturbing slice of French noir.Daniel, a French artist, is on a break near Barcelona. Driving down a road one night, a youJesus, that was a dark and disturbing slice of French noir.Daniel, a French artist, is on a break near Barcelona. Driving down a road one night, a young woman throws herself in front of his car in an apparent act of suicide. When he goes to the body, however, he realises she is still alive. Fearful of the consequences, he takes the girl back to his hotel. She awakes with severe amnesia, remembering nothing of her previous life. Daniel then becomes obsessed with her, instilling himself as her boyfriend and the central character in her new life.But, as he delves deeper into her forgotten past, he discovers the real, shocking reason she threw herself in front of his car.Grisly, grim and weaving from noir into horror, this is a very effective and highly creepy novel. The only complaint is in the editing - it is absolutely full of mistakes and typos....more

review: BINDLESTIFF by Wayne Holloway.This is a marauding, arrogant, inconsistent, savage, brilliant, bloody-fucking-mess of a novel. And I really enjoyed it.BINDLESTIFF by Wayne Holloway.This is a marauding, arrogant, inconsistent, savage, brilliant, bloody-fucking-mess of a novel. And I really enjoyed it. But would recommend to pretty much no-one I know. Most people would hate it.It's partly a dytopian road movie. Partly the writer's Hollywood-bastardised screenplay of the movie. Partly the writer's attempt to get the movie made in Hollywood lunches and money-board meetings. And partly a savage set of essays dismantling modern America, cinena, identity, race and a load more.Jeez. It's a knackering, head-fuck of a book, the kind of thing you've just got to let yourself be swept away by. But you'd probably hate it, anyway, whoever you are.The kind of book that makes you glad small presses exist, places that publish novels that push boundaries but will never make anyone a penny. I've been trying to think of something to compare it to and the best I can come up with is The Sellout. It's got that same kind of don't-give-a-fuck attitude. Phew....more

title: The Abortion
author: Brautigan, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well it's great, obviously. Brautigan was such a strange, unique genius. I have become a little obsessed with him in recent months.The Abortion is a tWell it's great, obviously. Brautigan was such a strange, unique genius. I have become a little obsessed with him in recent months.The Abortion is a tender novel, tackling a heavy subject with a light, poetic touch. It starts with the narrator, a 31-year-old librarian of sorts. This, however, is a very different kind of library - it is open to unpublished manuscripts from anyone who wants to write one. Just rock up with your book and pop it on the shelf.One day a girl named Vida shows up with her book and ends up staying and starting a relationship with the librarian. Vida is an oddity too - her beauty is so extreme it has ruined her life. It causes car crashes, turns men into dribbling wrecks, makes women hate her on sight.Vida soon becomes pregnant and the story follows the pair to Tijuana for an abortion.Brautigan uses this set-up to explore lots of issues, including gender, personal satisfaction and the weight of everyday life. It's Brautigan, so it's odd and whimsical and full of just incredible turns of phrase and wonderful descriptions. His books are celebrations of the written word, no less so than right here....more

author: Kelley, William Melvin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Described on the cover as the 'lost giant of American literature', Kelley's tremendous novel left me scratching my head as to why it isn't considered Described on the cover as the 'lost giant of American literature', Kelley's tremendous novel left me scratching my head as to why it isn't considered a central part of the modern US canon.In 1957, a young black farmer shoots his livestock, salts his fields and burns down his house. He then walks away from his fictional southern state. Every other black citizen follows his lead.From this brilliant set-up, Kelley tells the story of young Tucker Caliban, his ancestors and their masters, owners and bosses, entirely through the eyes of the white people left behind in town.There are a lot of moving parts in this novel but they tie together beautifully come the end. It's at times hopeful and cynical, moral and immoral, simple and complex. Almost 60 years after it was first published it feels incredibly fresh and would sit happily alongside the works of Ellison, Baldwin and other great writers on civil rights in the US....more

review: What a ripper! This is a quiet, original and inspiring dystopia written from the perspective of a community of First Nation Canadians in northern OntaWhat a ripper! This is a quiet, original and inspiring dystopia written from the perspective of a community of First Nation Canadians in northern Ontario.A harsh winter is coming to the remote reservation and life is made harder by the loss of communication with the south. Then the power goes, too. Family members arrive from the cities reporting of civil unrest and the collapse of society. It's not long before outsiders arrive, desperate and wild with fear and hunger, changing the community forever.Not just a dystopian tale, Rice's novel is a subtle exploration of race, history and the preservation of culture and customs. Yes, it is a little clunky in places, but it is such an original take on an oversaturated genre that you can easily forgive it....more

review: EUPHORIA by Heinz Helle.If only it weren't Austrian, I'd say this is absolutely a Brexit novel. Five 30-something friends return from a week in a mounEUPHORIA by Heinz Helle.If only it weren't Austrian, I'd say this is absolutely a Brexit novel. Five 30-something friends return from a week in a mountainside cabin to find the world they left behind ruined. Whole towns are burnt to the ground, bodies lie strewn everywhere, cars are piled up on the roads. All very familiar from many such books. But Helle does do something different with Euphoria. For a start, his characters aren't likeable, rational, determined romantics like you find in much dystopian literature. They are pretty much a bunch of pricks. I mean, they are fairly normal in most ways but they are greedy and arrogant and commit a couple of appalling acts and show no remorse whatsoever. Helle also adds some interesting satirical strands - Euro notes being useful only to start fires; glimpses of planes flying overhead, suggesting it is Austria alone that has been cut off; the German border protected by landmines. All scream of Brexit dystopia!Not a great book, by any standards. The characterisation is lacking and it never really goes anywhere. But it is quite well written and has some interesting ideas....more

review: FRIDAY BLACK by Nana Kwame Adeji-Brenya.This is an astonishing collection of debut stories by a young American with a raw, powerful voice. I intended FRIDAY BLACK by Nana Kwame Adeji-Brenya.This is an astonishing collection of debut stories by a young American with a raw, powerful voice. I intended to leaf through the opening pages but was so captivated that I couldn't stop.The opening story, The Finkelstein 5, is the best modern short story I have read and is worth the price of the book on its own. A white man leaves his local library with his two children in tow. Feeling threatened by the presence of five black children outside, he abruptly gets his chainsaw from the car and beheads them all. He is cleared by a court, which agrees he was acting in self defence. This sparks a series of retaliations. It is a truly shocking, terrifying story.There is also Zimmer Land, set in a theme park where folks pay to defend their fake homes against black loiterers, shooting them with bb guns as they attack.It is a striking collection, genuinely shocking and scary how close to real life Adeji-Brenya's fantasies are....more

review: IN WATERMELON SUGAR by Richard Brautigan.It's been years since I have been addicted to an author's books but I think that is happening with Brautigan.IN WATERMELON SUGAR by Richard Brautigan.It's been years since I have been addicted to an author's books but I think that is happening with Brautigan. That is two in a week and I feel like I want to go buy them all right now!This is typical Brautigan - magical, absurd, funny, sweet, grotesque, touching. It is a simple story in many ways, about new love and a scorned lover. But his fantastical imagery and wild imagination make it something completely unique and utterly bizarre.Told in short chapters, it is set in an imagined commune called watermelon sugar, where all types of things can be made from processed watermelon sugar and people don't have regular names and rivers run through living rooms and bodies are buried in trout hatcheries.It's nuts but it's just so, so addictive. Can't wait to read more Brautigan!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A MEAL IN WINTER by Hubert Mingarelli.This is a skillful, subtle French novel which will make uncomfortable reading for many people.It is a simple stoA MEAL IN WINTER by Hubert Mingarelli.This is a skillful, subtle French novel which will make uncomfortable reading for many people.It is a simple story of three soldiers on a mission in the bitterly cold coutryside who stop at an abandoned cottage and cook a meal. All sounds nice enough.However, these are Nazi soldiers, they have a Jewish captive in tow and the cottage is in Poland.Mingarelli's approach is so human, his touch so light, that you read page after page, enjoying the story, sympathising with the tough life of the soldiers, completely forgetting you are reading about one of the most horrific events in modern history.The humanization of Nazis is hugely controversial and the kind of thing authors don't often get away with in the UK. But it is necessary and, as much as we may hate it, true. The soldiers express horror at what is happening in the camps, they have sympathy with the captured Jew. They worry about family members back at home. They crave a hot meal. They are human. But are they evil? Is it possible to participate in evil acts and simultaneously regret them? Is it possible that good people can be swept up in shocking, brutal crimes? How much did average Nazi soldiers believe in what was ordered from above?This is a book full of uncomfortable truths and uncomfortable questions, especially for British readers, who have long been exposed to the simple rhetoric of good vs evil, right vs wrong, when it comes to World War 2.Mingarelli has done such a powerful job with this short, spare but important novel. It will stay with me for a long while....more

review: SOMBRERO FALLOUT by Richard Brautigan.Thanks to Andy for reminding me of Brautigan last week - I popped straight to the library and picked this one upSOMBRERO FALLOUT by Richard Brautigan.Thanks to Andy for reminding me of Brautigan last week - I popped straight to the library and picked this one up. It's a great read! I mean, it's way out there, but it is a lot of fun.The book follows two strands. Firstly, a middle-aged writer pining over his lost Japanese lover. Secondly, a short story he started and then threw in the bin starts to take on a life of its own - a freezing sombrero falls to the ground in the middle of a small town, in front of the town mayor. The sombrero incident sparks a series of catastrophic events which lead to rioting, murder, bombing, helicopter crashes and more! Madcap brilliance from this very unique writer....more

review: Violent, hugely disturbing, at times strangely erotic. Enriquez, an Argentinian author and journalist, has written a very decent collection which, on Violent, hugely disturbing, at times strangely erotic. Enriquez, an Argentinian author and journalist, has written a very decent collection which, on the face of it, are essentially horror stories, propelled forward by murder, ghosts, beheadings and haunted houses. But they all possess a political force, whether it be the feminism behind women's self-immolation in the title story, or the ghosts of police brutality in The Inn.Some stories are better than others (my favouries were The Dirty Kid and Adela's House) but they are all worthy of inclusion. I just had a little fatigue by the end - perhaps they are better read one or two at a time....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a delicious novella. I really like Enard, he always has something interesting to say about the mediterranean and the cultures of Europe and thThis is a delicious novella. I really like Enard, he always has something interesting to say about the mediterranean and the cultures of Europe and the Arab world.In this alternate history, it is 1506 and the great painter Michealangelo has fled Rome. He is invited by the Great Turk, the sultan Bayezid II, to design a bridge across the Golden Horn. Keen to eclipse his nemisis Leonardo Da Vinci, whose designs have already been rejected by the sultan, he heads for Constantinople. Here he draws, tours the great city and falls for a beautiful singer of indeterminate sex.In reality, Michealangelo did indeed flee the capital at this time. He was being stiffed financially by the ruling powers and had had enough. He really was invited by Bayezid to build a bridge but rejected, probably fearful of reprisals from Rome.Enard weaves fact and fiction, history and fantasy, into a light, intruiging, evocative tapestry, full of interesting characters. This serves as a great introduction to a superb contemporary writer....more

But everyone he writes about seems to die.There is a Kafkaesque feel about much if the book, steeped as it is in paranoia and peopled with corrupt officials and layers of truths and un-truths.It sags a little at times but all comes together for a wondeful finale. review: Another gorgeous novel by this masterful Norwegian storyteller. It is the beginning of the Winter War and Russian troops are invading Finland. In one Another gorgeous novel by this masterful Norwegian storyteller. It is the beginning of the Winter War and Russian troops are invading Finland. In one small town, the last of the residents are evacuating, leaving bonfires in their homes, 'gifts to Finland' they call them, razing the homesteads to the ground so the invaders cannot use them.But Timo refuses to leave. The village idiot, they call him, but really he is just a simple logger. He was born here and will die here and is not scared of anything. So he waits in the sooty, ruined town, for the Russians.This is a unique and intruiging story, set in the cold, bitter, beautiful Finnish north and told with Jacobsen's trademark spare prose. Not as brilliant as his International Booker-shortlisted The Unseen, but still a very fine tale, perfect for a cold winter's eve....more

review: Ooooh yes. Very, very good book, this one. On the surface it's the story of a group of people spending the summer living in a roundhouse, re-enacting Ooooh yes. Very, very good book, this one. On the surface it's the story of a group of people spending the summer living in a roundhouse, re-enacting the lives of iron-age Britons. But, for such a short book, there is a tonne of stuff going on beneath the narrative.One half of the group is a northern family, consisting of an overbearing, abusive father, his whipped wife and their teenage daughter. They are joined by a southern professor and three of his students, more liberal minded and less commited to the project than their hosts.This set-up leaves Moss a framework to explore a whole host if issues, most prominantly changing gender roles, class differences and societal change.It is all done with huge skill and the tension created is chilling, as the novel builds to a traumatic, troubling ending. Contemporary British writing at its finest....more

title: The Color of Water: A Black Man's Tribute to His White Mother
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Book that leave you in tears are rare. Those which have you weeping and laughing at several different points, rarer still. James McBride's memoir, subBook that leave you in tears are rare. Those which have you weeping and laughing at several different points, rarer still. James McBride's memoir, subtitled A Black Man's Tribute to His White Mother, is a deeply emotional and very beautiful tribute to an astonishing woman.Ruth McBride Jordan was a Polish immigrant, raised in the divided south by a cowering, polio-stricken mother and abusive rabbi father. But somehow she had bravery where most others held only hate and fear - she stepped across the racial divide. Ruth left her family behind and married a black man in New York, with whom she had eight children. When he died, she married another and made her kids an even 12.Together they scratched out a full, hectic and rich life in the Red Hook projects and later Queens, battling poverty, prejudice and sometimes each other. Incredibly, every one of her 12 children graduated from college and went on to great things, largely by the force of her love and her will.This memoir - told in alternate chapters by Ruth and James - is as moving a book as I have ever read and is the kind of story that makes you proud to be human and to be alive....more

He is a very fine Australian storyteller.JaxTHE SHEPHERD'S HUT by Tim Winton.Very good, indeed. This was my first Winton and I thoroughly enjoyed it. He is a very fine Australian storyteller.Jaxie's fifteen, his mother has died and he works with his abusive dad (whom he calls Captain Wankbag) in his butcher shop. One night he comes home to find Wankbag dead, so he panics and runs to the vast saltflats. The book then becomes survivalist fiction in a landscape whose terrain and brutality are so harsh and alien to most people that it feels post-apocolyptic.While the plot isn't entirely original, the setting certainly is and Winton has a feral, potty-mouthed and very convincing narrater in Jaxie.There are parrallels with McCarthy's The Road and Carrasco's Out in the Open but Winton does enough to make The Shepherd's Hut stand out on its own. I can't wait to read more by him....more

review: I think I may have missed something with this book.Petterson's story, if it can really be called that, is partly about the incidents that occurred oneI think I may have missed something with this book.Petterson's story, if it can really be called that, is partly about the incidents that occurred one summer in the life of the narrator Trond. Staying in a forest cabin with his father, Trond interacts with locals, rides horses and helps his father with logging. This is all told as dream-like memories by the much older Trond as he takes stock of his life as it begins to wind to a close and assesses the way these forming years affected him.About a third of the way through I was in love with the novel - the gorgeous setting of northern Norway, the spare and beautiful prose, the tender coming-of-age story. But it just stops flat. Petterson introduces several plotlines that lead nowhere, loads of characters find no resolution and it all becomes a bit dull.Now, that may well all be true to real life but I'm not sure I want it from a novel. And I can live without five-page descriptions of an old man getting out of bed on a morning....more

review: This beautiful, nostalgic classic novel delivers a fascinating insight into life on the great plains for the pioneer families.Written in an accessibleThis beautiful, nostalgic classic novel delivers a fascinating insight into life on the great plains for the pioneer families.Written in an accessible style, My Antonia tells the story of Jim Burden, a boy who arrives on his grandparents' Nebraska farm at the same time as The Shimerda family, Bohemian immigrants looking for a new life. The novel follows Jim and the Shimerdas' eldest daughter Antonia as they strike up a loving, lifelong friendship.The first part of the novel is irresistable, telling as it does the youngsters' life growing up on their respective farms as their families battle the land for a living. It does dip a little in the middle as the focus switches to prairie towns but picks up again for a moving, if sentimental, ending.Overall it's a very beautiful novel and well worth anyone's time....more

This novella, the first in a collection of four titled Sicilian Uncles, THE AMERICAN AUNT by Leonardo Sciascia.Why have I never read Sciascia before? This novella, the first in a collection of four titled Sicilian Uncles, is just great.It's a coming-of-age story about a young man in small Sicilian town at the end of WW2. The Americans have arrived to 'liberate' the locals, many of whom want nothing of the sort. The boy and his friend tag on to an Italian-American soldier, who tells of life in Brooklyn, where the boy's aunt also lives. When the war is finished the family and their neighbours are torn over Sicily's future, with communists, fascists, socialists and seperatists all in a single family. The American aunt also visits with her family, bringing presents and resentment.It is a fabulous story, full of rich detail, with the feel of a novel despite being told in just 50-odd packed pages....more

But this felt a little bit average.Frances, a Manhatten socialite, is ruined after, well, spending all her money. So she sells everything that isn't nailed down and flees to a friend's apartment in Paris, with her oddball 32-year-old son Malcolm in tow. The odd couple tour the city, all the time acquiring weird hangers-on and throwing away the last of their euros.This is all very deWittian and it all builds to a typically farcical big finale. Which is fine. The book is fine. It's just that some of the gags don't quite land and it doesn't have the same drive as either Undermajordomino Minor or The Sisters Brothers. review: THE MAN WHO CAME UPTOWN by George Pelecanos.Pelecanos isn't really a crime writer, though that's where he's often lumped. He writes around crime, rathTHE MAN WHO CAME UPTOWN by George Pelecanos.Pelecanos isn't really a crime writer, though that's where he's often lumped. He writes around crime, rather than about it. His stories are about people down on their luck and trying to make the most of things. Closer to Willy Vlautin or early Charles Willeford than Lee Child.Anyway, his new novel, The Man Who Came Uptown, is about Michael Hudson, newly released from prison and trying to go straight. Hudson has a new-found love of books, thanks to the prison book club. The novel centres on Hudson's attempts to build a life on the outside, using books as his inspiration.It's well written and heartfelt and Pelecanos takes the chance to riff on his favourite writers, from Elmore Leonard to Charles Portis and Willeford (including a last line straight from Willeford's Pick-Up). I like Pelecanos, even if he stays pretty safe with all his novels set in DC and featuring tweaks on fairly similar stories....more

review: Aghrrr, this book is a bit of a mess. What is it about? Who knows. Well, not what the synopsis says, anyway.The sort-of plot revolves around Vernon SuAghrrr, this book is a bit of a mess. What is it about? Who knows. Well, not what the synopsis says, anyway.The sort-of plot revolves around Vernon Subutex, a former record shop owner now bankrupt and homeless. He dodders around Paris, calling up old friends asking to sleep on their sofa, often shagging them when he gets his foot in the door.The teaser on the back cover says Vernon is in possession of some recordings of his friend, the recently deceased rock legend Alex Bleach, and that he is being hounded for the tapes by fans and the media. But that's a red herring as it is hardly mentioned and isn't at all integral to the story.Much of the book comes from the points of view of the many people Vernon encounters on his journeys. This gives the novel an episodic feel and makes it very hard to follow any semblance of a thread. These characters are often only surface-deep charciatures and there only to show some deviant personality trait.Though there are some funny moments and certain interesting characters this felt like a deliberate attempt to shock bourgoeis readers and critics. Frustrating.And one other thing - it is full of errors. Very lazy publishing....more

review: THERE, THERE by Tommy Orange.This book has been massively hyped by every  feature out there and the quotes on the cover are praise lavished by bTHERE, THERE by Tommy Orange.This book has been massively hyped by every  feature out there and the quotes on the cover are praise lavished by big names (Atwood, James, Erdrich). Absolutely none of that hype is justified.What There, There is is an average or worse piece of contemporary literary fiction. It is the product of someone who has turned up at creative writing school with a heap of short stories and someone has helped him shoehorn it all together to make a novel.Now, that is not to say Orange doesn't have anything to say. His prologue is a biting potted history of the white man's persecution of the native American.But what follows is a novel narrated by about 12 characters in less than 300 pages, leaving no character fully developed and most with similar voices. The plot is flimsy and incoherent and nothing really ties together convincingly.I started reading this book with a lot of good will. Who wouldn't want to read a book by a native American dissecting his culture's place in modern America? But it isn't that at all. It's limp modern fiction with big publisher backing. I was hoping for a native American Ralph Ellison or Richard Wright but it falls well short of that. Where's the passion, man?...more

review: THE WICKED GO TO HELL by Frederic Dard (tr. by David Coward).This is a quick, tough and fairly satisfying 50s noir which was originally a play, then aTHE WICKED GO TO HELL by Frederic Dard (tr. by David Coward).This is a quick, tough and fairly satisfying 50s noir which was originally a play, then a film, then novel.The novel starts with an unnamed police officer being given instructions to go undercover as a prisoner, stage a jailbreak and find out what he can about a suspect who won't talk to police. It is then up to the reader to work out who is the criminal and who is the cop as the narrative progresses.Simenon's stamp is all over Dard's work with simple, often funny set pieces and the narrative always has something deeper going on. Here, I guess, is the question of whether it's the labels we place on a man that define him, or is it the way he behaves? Not a bad read at all but it would suit the stage brilliantly, I imagine....more

review: BLACK SUNSET by Clancy Sigal.This memoir of a 50s Hollywood agent is a real treat. Sigal was a fascinating figure. After serving in Germany during theBLACK SUNSET by Clancy Sigal.This memoir of a 50s Hollywood agent is a real treat. Sigal was a fascinating figure. After serving in Germany during the clean-up at the end of WW2, he attempted to kill Goering at the Nurenburg trials, being disarmed by a fellow soldier moments before.He returned to the US and went to UCLA on the GI bill. He then became part of a communist cell and fell into a job as a talent agent at Sam Jaffe's agency, where they handled everyone from jobbing scriptwriters like John Fante and James Agee to huge stars like Humphrey Bogart.Black Sunset is the brilliant story of this period of his life as he works the sleazy world of the movies while being hounded by FBI agents during the height of McCarthyism. Anyone interested in the movies or McCarthyism will love this book. The writing is glorious, like James Ellroy living in Chandler's LA. It's great....more

review: I enjoyed this short, fable-like novel from one of Turkey's most famous writers, and found it surprisingly relevent to today's world. Hilal is killed I enjoyed this short, fable-like novel from one of Turkey's most famous writers, and found it surprisingly relevent to today's world. Hilal is killed by his wife's lover in a fit of rage. The lover is then murdered by villagers but it is the wife, Esme, who is forever blamed for Hilal's murder.The inhabitants of the village then spend decades convincing Esme's son to kill her as none of them want to do it.The writing is simple and poetic, biblical almost. And the themes of jealousy and violence against women are still relevent today....more
